thread.title: Screams of terror seconds after suspected drink-driver of Mercedes mows down five car wash workers

title: Screams of terror seconds after suspected drink-driver of Mercedes mows down five car wash workers

organizations.name: met's roads and transport policing command
mercedes benz metropolitan police hospitals dangerous

text:
Screams of terror seconds after suspected drink-driver of Mercedes mows down five car wash workers WARNING: DISTURBING FOOTAGE. Horrified witnesses claimed angry bystanders chased the suspected drunk driver down the street shouting 'Why have you done this?' Share By Rhian Lubin Jamie Bullen 14:45, 26 FEB 2017 Updated 14:54, 26 FEB 2017 News Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch Next Game of Thrones star and UK's tallest man Neil Fi Watch this video again Watch Next Tory makes controversial comment about disability 1:22 Princess Diana appears gloveless at just a few of 1:26 At the scene in Bellingham where five people rush 0:33 Shocking moment pranksters posing as police offic 0:58 Intense moment axeman is TASERED outside UK shopp 0:56 Baroness Chakrabarti blames the WEATHER for Copel 0:35 Stan Collymore believes Wayne Rooney deserves a b 0:26 10-week-old sloth bear rescued after being found 0:28 Video will play in Exclusive: Immediate aftermath of horror crash in Bellingham Share this video Watch Next Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email These scenes of carnage show the aftermath of a horror crash in south London after the suspected drunk-driver of a Mercedes mowed down five pedestrians - leaving a man fighting for his life.
Dramatic footage captured how desperate bystanders tended to motionless victims as witnesses scream in terror following the smash in Bromley Road, Bellingham.
Horrified witnesses told how the suspected drunk driver, a well-dressed man, was chased down the street by angry bystanders who shouted: "Why have you done this?"
They added victims were left covered in blood after the grey-coloured Mercedes mounted a pavement outside a car wash and struck a wall at 8.20am.
Desperate bystanders tend to victims (Photo: © MGN Limited) Five people were injured when a Mercedes mounted a pavement in south London (Photo: © MGN Limited) Witness Minasu Towolawi ,26, told The Mirror: "We were on our way to church when we heard these screams.
"There's usually quite a lot of fighting round here so I just thought it was that but then my mum said, 'that's not that kind of scream..."
"We saw these people lying on the floor covered in blood, other people around them were screaming and crying, trying to help.
The driver has been arrested on suspicion of drink-driving (Photo: PA) A man is fighting for his life in hospital (Photo: PA) "I saw a well dressed man running down the street with some men chasing after him screaming, 'What the f*** have you done? Why have you done this?' Then the police came and arrested him.
"I don't understand how one person can do that to five people."
Another witness, Colin Liddell, 29, told how he saw the driver turn the car around at the end of the street and speed towards the car wash.
He said: "He turned around and sped towards the wall and hit a bollard and five people before smashing into a wall. At the time we thought they were all dead. The one that was in the car then ran away."
Five people were rushed to hospital.
Police said a 25-year-old man remained in a critical condition.
The driver has been arrested on suspicion of drink-driving and causing serious injury by dangerous driving.
(Photo: Twitter@tinklyboo) The Met Police initially said three people were fighting for their lives but a woman, 35, and an another 25-year-old man are now serious but stable.
Two men, aged 36 and 46, suffered minor injuries.
Detectives from the Met's Roads and Transport Policing Command have launched an investigation into the crash.
Anyone who witnessed the collision is asked to contact the Serious Collision Investigation Unit's witness appeal line on 020 8285 1574 or via 101.
